column8: The judgement frogs come from the 1999 film Magnolia directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, a film that I greatly admire because of its interconnecting storylines and the underlying theme of unexplained events.  The design is based upon a scene at the end of the film in which San Fernando Valley is showered by frogs causing chaos on the streets.  Their are many interpretations of this scene however my opinion is that the raining frogs bear religious connotation, which is referenced several times throughout the film and that it is God judging the characters and their sins.
column21: A t-shirt admiring P. T. Anderson's film Magnolia, and specially the famous raining-frogs scene. From weadmire.net.

column8:
Byron was an infamous poet of the Romantic era, Known for his debaucherous lifystyle of love affairs with both women and men. After receiving criticism for his incestous and homosexual ways, he left England for a mediterranean life, never to return home. Yet word of his exploits made news back home. Byron proudly boasted that he slept with a different woman for 200 nights, he also had relations with his half sister, and many men. He was treated for gonorrhea, and possibly had syphilis.
Despite his deviated lifestyle he was a brilliant poet, he brought into being the concept of the 'Byronic hero', and greatly influenced poetry, opera, novel, music and painting.
column21: A t-shirt showing much deserved admiration for the 'Mad & Bad' Lord Byron. Legendary romantic poet, womaniser and all-round rebel. What's not to love?

column5: Default Category/Music,Default Category/Arts & Culture,Default Category/Popular Culture
column8:
This t-shirt design is in admiration of London's amazing far reaching music scene.

London's music scene is hard to beat. It has got to one of the best in the world with some of the greatest musicians and pop stars performing some of their biggest shows, and the numerous, quality gig venues and park festivals that constantly please the music loving populous.

There is also a strong and complex clubbing/dj/rave culture; from the mainstream clubs in Picadilly/Leicester Sq to the slightly more grunge and promiscuous soho, though to the more alternative camden and shoreditch. Not to mention the thousands of other clubs throughout the rest of london.
There are high end, worldwide franchised clubs like Pacha and Ministry of Sound, right down to the gritty and personal bunker sized clubs like Public Life (situated in an old underground public street toilet), not to mention the countless raves like mulletover and the late secretsundaze that sprawl through the warehouses, empty buildings, and carparks of london.

Picturing the london skyline as a soundwave, this t-shirt celebrates this culture.
column21: Picturing the london skyline as a soundwave, the shirt celebrates the Ministry of Sound.

column8: Mathieu Kassovitz’s 1995 instant classic La Haine had a revitalising effect on French cinema. The film’s main focus is on the life of 3 friends and a missing Policeman’s revolver the day after a night of rioting in the Paris suburbs. Shot entirely in grainy black and white, the films main message seems to be anti-police with flashes of dark humour and edge of the seat tension. The film pays homage to classic gangster movies throughout with one character spraying over an advert “the world is yours” replacing “yours” with “ours” with a nod to Brian De Palma’s Scarface.  Celebrate a great French film wear our Le Monde est a vous t shirt.
column21: Le Monde est a vous T-shirt, from weadmire.net.
